etymology.description: 足(足) (zú, "foot") + 止(止) (zhǐ, "stop") = semantic: foot + phonetic: stop -> toe
etymology.interpretation: The character combines 足(足) (zú, "foot") as the semantic indicator and 止(止) (zhǐ, "stop") as the phonetic component to represent the idea of a 'toe,' which is a part of the foot.

examples.chinese: 他的趾因寒冷而僵硬了(他的趾因寒冷而僵硬了)。
examples.pinyin: tā de zhǐ yīn hánlěng ér jiāngyìng le.
examples.english: His toe became stiff due to the cold.

examples.chinese: 我走路时(我走路時)，不小心扭到了趾(不小心扭到了趾)。
examples.pinyin: wǒ zǒulù shí, bù xiǎoxīn niǔ dào le zhǐ.
examples.english: While I was walking, I accidentally twisted my toe.

examples.chinese: 古代剑客战斗时(古代劍客戰鬥時)，常因疏忽伤及趾(常因疏忽傷及趾)。
examples.pinyin: gǔdài jiànkè zhàndòu shí, cháng yīn shūhū shāng jí zhǐ.
examples.english: Ancient swordsmen often injured their toes due to carelessness during battles.
